results.title: Regarding Henry
results.creator_credit: Mike Nichols, Scott Rudin and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Harrison Ford stars as Henry Turner, a successful but ruthless New York lawyer who must win at any cost, even at the expense of his family. A single, freakish gunshot brings Henry’s world crashing down as he is left incapacitated and with no memory of the life he used to lead. Now, faced with starting over, Henry will learn the painful truth about his life and rediscover the family he never really had. Also starring Annette Bening as Henry’s long-suffering wife, this thought provoking film questions the importance of money over family and ultimately - the price of happiness.

results.title: Election
results.creator_credit: Alexander Payne, Keith Samples, David Gale, Ron Yerxa, Albert Berger, Bona Fide Productions, MTV Films and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Matthew Broderick plays Jim McAllister, a popular and well respected teacher at George Washington Carver High School. Reese Witherspoon is Tracy Flick, A-Grade student and No. 1 candidate for the student body president. Tracy is confident that her campaign for presidency is going smoothly until Mr McAllister decides to disrupt proceedings and introduce opposition to her as yet unchallenged ride to the top. More than a teenage flick, director Alexander Payne has satirized the popular genre to investigate notions of political and moral corruption. In a clever piece of casting, Matthew Broderick exchanges his Ferris Bueller persona for the devoted and concerned teacher who is slightly burned out from years of teaching. Add to this the disillusionment of a dull marriage and the shameful dismissal of McAllister’s best friend and colleague, and the esteemed civic teacher’s sense of democracy is put to the test. Brilliant performances, subtle humour and an excellent screenplay (an Oscar nomination for Payne and co-writer Jim Taylor). Surprisingly, this film was a box office sleeper. Based on the novel by Tom Perrotta.

results.title: The Hitcher
results.creator_credit: Robert Harmon, Kip Ohman, David Bombyk and Silver Screen Partners
results.brief_description: This dark, violent suspense thriller centres around the strange psychological bond between a travelling serial killer and one of his intended victims. Travelling from Chicago to California, Jim Halsey narrowly escapes an accident when he falls asleep at the wheel. To help stay awake, he picks up hitchhiker, John Ryder, but soon discovers his error when Ryder threatens his life. Although Jim manages to escape, he is soon led on a game of cat-and-mouse across the Texas highways, where Ryder leaves a trail of corpses for Jim to discover. Cast includes Rutger Hauer, C. Thomas Howell, Jennifer Jason Leigh and Jeffrey de Munn.

results.title: Best in show
results.creator_credit: Christopher Guest, Karen Murphy and Castle Rock Entertainment
results.brief_description: Director Christopher Guest and cast members from his previous film ‘Waiting for Guffman’ reunite in this mockumentary following the exploits of five dogs and their handlers before the Mayflower Kennel Club Dog Show. Guest himself plays Harlan Pepper, a fly-fishing store owner and amateur ventriloquist, who decides to enter his beloved bloodhound Hubert in the prestigious competition. His competition includes “Winky”, a Norwich terrier, owned by neurotic couple Gerry and Cookie Fleck (Eugene Levy and Catherine O’Hara) and “Beatrice” a high-strung Wiemaraner owned by preppy couple Meg and Hamilton Swan (Parker Posey and Michael Hitchcock). Also making the trip to Philadelphia are Scott (John Michael Higgins) and Stefan (Michael McKean), life-partners from New York and their beloved Shih Tzu “Miss Agnes”, and trophy wife Sheri Ann Cabot (Jennifer Coolidge) and her friend and dog trainer, Christy Cummings (Jane Lynch) and their poodle, two time ‘Mayflower Best in Show’ winner, “Rhapsody in White”, also known as Butch. Cast also includes Fred Willard, Bob Balaban, Ed Begley Jr and Lewis Arquette.

results.title: Stella does tricks
results.creator_credit: Coky Giedroyc, Adam Barker, Channel Four Television, British Film Institute, Sidewalk Productions and Compulsive Films
results.brief_description: Having escaped Glasgow and the sexual abuse of the father she once adored, Stella winds up on the streets of London as a teenage prostitute with a vicious middle-aged pimp. Despite her bleak and seemingly hopeless circumstances, a streak of anger and yearning drives her to escape the sadistic men who dominate her life, but not before her pimp exacts one last act of savage abuse. The film shifts abruptly between Stella’s romanticised interior world of memories and fantasies, and the real world where her rage erupts into acts of vandalism and often poetic revenge on the men who have mistreated her. Giedroyc draws on her former experience as a director of realist drama and documentary for British television, handling the often confronting subject matter frankly and suffusing the film with a sense of outrage and urgency. Cast includes Kelly Macdonald, James Bolam, Hans Matheson and Ewan Stewart.

results.title: The Boy who stopped talking = De Jongen die niet meet praatt
results.creator_credit: Ben Sombogaart, Burny Bos and Bos Bros Film - TV Productions
results.brief_description: The Boy who stopped talking is the story of Memo, (Ercan Orhan) a nine-year-old child living in eastern Turkey in a small traditional Kurdish village. Memo has the important roles in the village of postman, which also involves reading the mail to the illiterate, and shepherd. He lives there with his mother and young sister whilst his father works in The Netherlands in a shipyard. Memo’s happy, innocent existence is thrown into chaos one day when his father decides to relocate the family to The Netherlands to escape the dangers of the oncoming war in Turkey. Memo responds to this unhappy event by deciding to stop talking. A subplot involving illegal immigrants exposes their vulnerability and their exploitation at the hands of shady business owners. This gently observed film explores the effects that cultural dislocation has on children and their families. A local boy and classmate, Jeroen, tries to befriend Memo and aid his assimilation into school life. Memo resists his father’s imploring to break his silence, longing for his village, which is being ravaged by war. In Turkish and Dutch with English subtitles.

results.title: The Things of life = Les choses de la vie
results.creator_credit: Claude Sautet, Roland Girard, Raymond Danon, Jean Bolvary, Fida Cinematografica and Lira Films
results.brief_description: Pierre (Michel Piccoli) has a collision at a roadside intersection and as he battles for his life on the way to hospital, he reflects back on his life, particularly his relationships with his wife (Lea Massari) and his mistress (Romy Schneider). Sautet is a master of a refined form of bourgeois melodrama in which protagonists are jolted out of security and forced to re-examine the meaning of their lives and the value of marriage, family and love. In many ways, “Les Choses de la Vie”, made in 1969, takes the departures allowed for by the radical events of May 1968 not as a means for subverting aesthetics, but for examining the shifts this caused for middle-class morality and values. Pierre is torn by the duties he feels towards love and his duties as a father and husband to his son and wife. His recollections are all part of attempting to reconcile his conflicting desires with the truth of his own mortality. The film is based on the novel by Paul Guimard and the elegant film score is by Philippe Sarde. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Tokyo Olympiad [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Kon Ichikawa, Suketaro Taguchi, 13th Olympic Games Organising Committee and Toho Kabushiki Kaisha
results.brief_description: Ichikawa’s compression of the many hours of footage shot by 164 cameramen using 1031 cameras at the 1964 Olympics is the only sporting documentary to rival Riefenstahl’s Olympia. In contrast to Riefenstahl’s heroic paean to the human body, Ichikawa seeks out and pays tribute to human fallibility using the telephoto lens, slow motion and freeze frame, to probe and generate empathy. In place of a mundane and prosaic record of national teams competing in a succession of events, Ichikawa takes the occasion to stay in close with selected individuals, winners and losers, striving to overcome their limitations. As in Riefenstahl’s film the climax is the marathon, here presented as a tribute to, rather than a celebration of individual effort. A phenomenally successful film upon its theatrical release, Ichikawa illustrates that a search for human understanding sometimes presents insurmountable difficulties, sometimes there is room for optimism, but more often the ironic truth is that a gold medal provides no answer to the problems of living.

results.title: The Captive = La Captive
results.creator_credit: Chantal Akerman, Paolo Branco, Arte France and Gemini Films
results.brief_description: Chantal Akerman, one of contemporary cinema’s singular filmmakers, is the director of “La Captive”, a minimalist masterpiece about the complexities and ‘politics’ of male-female relations. Inspired by Marcel Proust’s “The Prisoner” (the fifth volume of “Remembrance of Things Past”), “La Captive” centres on Simon (Stanislas Merhar), a handsome, wealthy, young man, who lives in an opulent multi-levelled apartment with his grandmother, a maid, and Ariane (Sylvie Testud), his girlfriend and willing ‘captive’. We first see Simon stalking Ariane as she runs an errand, it gradually becomes apparent that he is compelled to control her every movement, to the point where he forcibly removes her from social gatherings and orders her how to bathe and when to join him in bed. Inflaming Simon’s suspicion and anxiety is Ariane’s close connection to a circle of women friends, especially, the beautiful, Andree (Olivia Bonamy), with whom she spends a lot of time. Increasingly distressed, Simon decides to terminate their relationship and drives Ariane to a grand seaside hotel for a final, tragic night together. Exactly why Ariane submits to Simon’s control remains largely unexplained. True to Akerman’s abstract, minimalist style, such ‘story’ details or emotional content are kept at bay to enable a more philosophical exploration of ideas of obsession, male-female vs. female-female relations, and the relation between control and desire. Akerman expertly fine-tunes story tension via rhythm, shot composition and her signature austere, elegant style. With more then a hint of Hitchcock’s “Vertigo”, Bresson’s “Une Femme Douce”, and Antonioni’s “L’Avenntura”, “La Captive” is a seminal film that questions the very possibility of an open and humane relationship between a man and woman. Beautifully shot by Sabine Lancelin and impeccably scored. In French with English subtitles.

True to Akerman’s abstract, minimalist style, such ‘story’ details or emotional content are kept at bay to enable a more philosophical exploration of ideas of obsession, male-female vs. female-female relations, and the relation between control and desire. Akerman expertly fine-tunes story tension via rhythm, shot composition and her signature austere, elegant style. With more then a hint of Hitchcock’s “Vertigo”, Bresson’s “Une Femme Douce”, and Antonioni’s “L’Avenntura”, “La Captive” is a seminal film that questions the very possibility of an open and humane relationship between a man and woman. Beautifully shot by Sabine Lancelin and impeccably scored. In French with English subtitles.
description_for_label: Chantal Akerman, one of contemporary cinema’s singular filmmakers, is the director of “La Captive”, a minimalist masterpiece about the complexities and ‘politics’ of male-female relations. Inspired by Marcel Proust’s “The Prisoner” (the fifth volume of “Remembrance of Things Past”), “La Captive” centres on Simon (Stanislas Merhar), a handsome, wealthy, young man, who lives in an opulent multi-levelled apartment with his grandmother, a maid, and Ariane (Sylvie Testud), his girlfriend and willing ‘captive’. We first see Simon stalking Ariane as she runs an errand, it gradually becomes apparent that he is compelled to control her every movement, to the point where he forcibly removes her from social gatherings and orders her how to bathe and when to join him in bed. Inflaming Simon’s suspicion and anxiety is Ariane’s close connection to a circle of women friends, especially, the beautiful, Andree (Olivia Bonamy), with whom she spends a lot of time. Increasingly distressed, Simon decides to terminate their relationship and drives Ariane to a grand seaside hotel for a final, tragic night together. Exactly why Ariane submits to Simon’s control remains largely unexplained. True to Akerman’s abstract, minimalist style, such ‘story’ details or emotional content are kept at bay to enable a more philosophical exploration of ideas of obsession, male-female vs. female-female relations, and the relation between control and desire. Akerman expertly fine-tunes story tension via rhythm, shot composition and her signature austere, elegant style. With more then a hint of Hitchcock’s “Vertigo”, Bresson’s “Une Femme Douce”, and Antonioni’s “L’Avenntura”, “La Captive” is a seminal film that questions the very possibility of an open and humane relationship between a man and woman. Beautifully shot by Sabine Lancelin and impeccably scored. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Aimee & Jaguar = Aimee and Jaguar
results.creator_credit: Max Farberbock, Gunter Rohrbach, Hanno Huth and Senator Film Production
results.brief_description: Based on the memoirs of Lilly Wust as recorded by Erica Fischer in her best-selling book, published in 1994, “Aimee and Jaguar” is a compelling love story that transgresses socially and politically imposed regulations around gender, race and culture. It tells the true story of two German women, one Jewish and one Aryan, who dared to fall deeply in love with each other at the height of the Holocaust. 1943- Lilly is a model bourgeois German mother of four children who indulges in affairs while husband is away fighting on the Eastern front. When she receives a love letter signed ‘Jaguar,’ she suspects a male admirer. But it is from the audacious Felice, a Jewish Resistance fighter, who initiates the passionate love affair that ignites between the two women amidst the bombing raids and anti-Semitic persecution. Inevitably it is a romance that is destined to end in tragedy. An immensely moving period drama, that also offers a visually impressive evocation of life in Berlin during WWII. In German with English subtitles.
